answers.answer: Dear casey59,Sometimes, this process may be associated with systemic medical conditions such as high blood pressure or diabetes. Other times, no known cause may be identified.Dr. FeldmanSandy T. Feldman, M.D., M.S.ClearView Eye and Laser Medical CenterSan Diego, California

question: what is the physiological process or reason for the brain to stop causing the eyes to focus together.?  My neuro opthamologist said that the brain just "gives up" trying to get the eyes to focus together.  I have intermittent extropia with up close diplopia.  Do the neurons atrophy or die that once controlled the ability of the eyes to stay focused?  I never had an eye muscle imblance before, I am 67, is it an aging issue?  I had a brain MRI which was fine and I do not have any of the diseases associated with diplopia.I know you see with your brain and it interprets the images from the optic nerve.  I am just puzzled as to why the brain stops causing the eye muscles to stay focused together? Any info on this process would be greatly appreciated< I have read a lot about this condition, but I haven't been able to get a clear understanding as to why this just "happens"
title: late onset decompensation  for binocular alignment
